title: Iraq Rocket Attack Targets U.S.-Led Coalition, in Test for Biden
sub_head: Assault kills a contractor and injures a U.S. service member and five other contractors; president is briefed
body:
A rocket attack on the U.S.-led coalition in northern Iraq on Sunday killed a contractor and injured a U.S. service member and five other contractors, the U.S. military said.
The development represents an early test for President Biden in his role as a commander-in-chief. Similar attacks in 2019 and 2020 led then-President Trump to order retaliatory airstrikes against the Iranian-backed militia group U.S. officials said were responsible.
U.S., Iraqi officials and officials in the Kurdish semiautonomous region said investigations were under way to identify who was responsible for the Sunday attack.
The U.S. has about 2,500 troops in Iraq, whose mission is to mentor Iraqi troops and Kurdish Peshmerga forces.
“Initial report that indirect fire landed on coalition forces in Erbil tonight,” Colonel Wayne Morotto, the spokesman for the U.S.-led military coalition, tweeted about the Sunday incident.
